item.title: Chad heads to the polls as Deby seeks fifth term
item.description: President Idriss Deby, who came to power in a military coup in 1990, is expected to remain in office.

item.title: Massive fire in crowded India temple kills scores
item.description: At least 83 killed and more than 200 injured at temple when fire engulfed packed building, officials say.

item.title: Pakistani troops kill dozens of rebels in Balochistan
item.description: Abdul Nabi Bangulzai - a "main commander" of separatist group in Balochistan - allegedly one of 34 fighters killed.

item.title: Turkey: US and Israel warn of 'imminent' attack threat
item.description: Countries urge citizens to evacuate immediately citing high-level threats against tourist areas throughout Turkey.

item.title: Families of Afghans killed in US drone raids seek probe
item.description: Relatives and tribal elders deny US and Afghan officials' claims the air strikes hit Taliban-associated fighters.

item.title: Is the migrants' deportation from Greece legal?
item.description: More migrants and refugees are being sent back from Greece to Turkey.

item.title: Rockets hit Afghan capital after Kerry visit
item.description: Police say three explosions struck Kabul's diplomatic area shortly after the visit by US Secretary of State John Kerry.

item.title: Panama Papers: Protesters demand Cameron's resignation
item.description: David Cameron's "mishandled" efforts to disclose interests in offshore trust triggers demonstration at party event.

item.title: Desperate refugees still struggling to reach Greece
item.description: Limited options dominate the current situation for stranded refugees after the EU-Turkey deal came into force.

item.title: Mohamed Abrini confesses to being 'man in the hat'
item.description: Prosecutors say the Belgian confessed to being the fugitive third attacker at Brussels airport bombing seen on video.

item.title: Syrian rebels capture key ISIL town north of Aleppo
item.description: Fighters say the seizure of al-Rai is a crucial step towards taking other ISIL strongholds in Syria.

item.title: 18 soldiers killed by Abu Sayyaf in the Philippines
item.description: Fierce daylong fighting on the southern Philippine island of Basilan also left 52 soldiers wounded.

item.title: Iraqis and Afghans drown as boat sinks off Greek island
item.description: Latest Aegean Sea disaster comes as people continue trying to reach Europe despite the EU-Turkey refugee-return deal.

item.title: Panama Papers: Have the media censored the story?
item.description: Can the corporate-owned media really hold the corporate world to account? Plus, Julian Assange on the Panama Papers.

item.title: Behind the Panama Papers
item.description: Investigative journalist Gerard Ryle talks about the reach of the story and the journalistic collaboration behind it.

item.title: Q&A: Julian Assange on the Panama Papers
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder speaks to Richard Gizbert about secrets, leaks and why all 11.5 million files should be published.

item.title: Sweden's backlash: Why the tide is turning for refugees
item.description: We speak to Swedish politicians and citizens to find out what is behind the current backlash against immigration.

item.title: Syrian Civil War: Search for alternative trading routes
item.description: The agreement with Jordan is the latest in Turkey's search for an alternative to the land route through Syria.

item.title: Deadly car bombing targets Mogadishu restaurant
item.description: At least three people, including a child, killed in massive explosion in Somali capital claimed by al-Shabab.

item.title: Yemen: Gunmen ambush troops, execute 20 by firing squad
item.description: Killings come as ceasefire between Yemen's warring parties is due to begin on Sunday.

item.title: American B-52 bombers deployed to Qatar for ISIL fight
item.description: US air force says powerful long-range bombers will target ISIL positions strategically without carpet-bombing.

item.title: Panama Papers: El Salvador raids Mossack Fonseca office
item.description: Documents and equipment seized by authorities in investigation of Mossack Fonseca, firm at centre of data leak scandal.

item.title: Web musicians build audience amid bleak finances
item.description: Financial outlook for independent musicians can be bleak, but ambition to make music and getting heard keeps them going.

item.title: Panama Papers: How the Seychelles saved Syria
item.description: Panama Papers revealed how a seemingly insular regime has harnessed the tools of globalisation to ensure its survival.

item.title: In Mozambique, the children too poor to learn
item.description: Despite improvements in education access, many rural children are still pressed into work to supplement family income.
